53.pros: Compensation for an entry-level employee fresh out of college or certificate programs is not bad, it's a good starting point.Work-Life balance is pretty good. I'm not working nights or weekends so that's great, and I sign off at a decent hour.Company Culture: People are nice, friendly, and are absolutely willing to help if you have questions (some people you learn to not bother so much, but that's with any company). There are Slack channels for your interests. Career Growth is meh. There are plenty of opportunities to learn and strengthen your skills.
53.cons: It's definitely a stepping stone sort of place for entry-level hires. I can see why many leave after 2 years at least or 4 years at most. (If you feel like you're not learning anything after 1-2 years, leave. Years of experience mean little if you don't have any projects or skills to show for it.)Compensation: it's a good starting point for entry-level positions, but compensation can take a long time to grow with you if you're planning to stay for 3-5+ years.  Company Culture: Teams/Departments tend to be siloed. If you're someone that values more personal project hand-offs, who likes to get to know their colleagues a little bit, it's achievable to do that but the environment can get a bit solitary and echo-ey at times.Career Growth: while *learning* opportunities are available and in decent amounts, being promoted into higher-level positions or getting promoted into having a higher salary, is actually quite difficult to achieve. It's dismal. I've met individuals who have been with IBM for 2 decades and only are just beginning to break into higher-level positions.Lay-offs are prevalent at times. It's not uncommon to have a lay-off season. In a similar vein, there's a significant turnover rate. (again, that depends on your department). Someone on the team may decide to leave within the year or just after a year of your arrival, thus increasing the workload for some people, which causes them to leave because the workload is too much, which puts more work onto more people and they leave, and that puts more work... you get the idea. It's a vicious cycle.

63.desc: IBM Cloud/Infra - Heavy on Politics; Race to the Bottom Strategy

63.cons: - Little room for professional or compensation growth- Miniscule performance bonuses & RSUs (big wigs get the big bonuses)- Very political; everyone trying to be first to impress the revolving door of VPs- Unsophisticated exec management; zero interest in dev (just acquire a company, and strip it down)- No focus on growth; just cutting costs; outsourcing to India is current strategy- Company is 50/50 people who add value vs. people who pontificate in meetings, but do little- Do a good job = get more work; someone resigns/laid off = get more work- Poor work/life balance depending on team; overnight demands; unreasonable deadlines/expectations- Senior management views employees as button pushing monkeys yet most can't even navigate a spreadsheet- Significant cronyism at exec/VP levels; internal people are not breaking that glass ceiling

93.cons: Your career will die here if you stay. The only people at this company are lifers or early career hires. You will most likely be working only with proprietary IBM products only. If you have no other choice, only stay here for a year at most. They hired hundreds of us in 2021 but had zero work for us. We learned nothing and have nothing to put on our resume for a year's worth of work experience.  Work is picking up now but projects don't have project managers running them. 268.desc: Good first job. But make sure to leave. Dinosaur of a company
268.pros: This is in my department specifically (older product so median age is probably ~53)Great WLB.People I work with are pretty laid back and I like them a lot. autonomy.
268.cons: No bonus or stock. Base is somewhat competitive. But you will not get market adjustments. I came in at $75k new grad. 2 years later new grads came in at $98k.I got a whopping $1k bonus once. Highest raise (non-promotion) was 3% (didn't get one prior year).You don't really work on new tech (department dependent). Very susceptible to falling behind on new technologies. Old technology. IBM has fallen so far behind. They think open spaces and using GitHub is going to attract all of the great talent. The CEO Arvind seems to be fairly logical and straight forward but he is known to chop heads. Another con, IBM is notorious for layoffs. However, in my department we've never been hit (*knocks on wood*)Super super bloated with managers. It's an upside down pyramid there. It is very very obvious how much (lack of) control each level manager has on a decision level. Old school type of mentality that they are trying to please their manager and so on up the ladder. We get pizza parties as rewards??

275.desc: Laid back, disorganized, lack of challenges
275.pros: The team that I am on is very laid back and is entirely made up of very considerate and respectful, though not especially driven, individuals. There is almost no pressure to get things done quickly and everyone works at their own pace. The work is easy. If you are looking for a place to coast by, this could be the team for you. But it's a crap shoot trying to get into a particular team within IBM.
275.cons: Management is disorganized and unfocused. Although we have new tasks every quarter, it is never clear to me why we are performing them. When I ask, nobody has a satisfactory answer.The work is TOO easy. There is a serious lack of interesting engineering challenges. Every engineering problem the team deals with either 1) has been solved already by open source software which merely needs to be applied correctly, or 2) is self-inflicted, caused by mistakes/poor decisions earlier in the team's history.Additionally, the compensation is below average for the role and region I am in. But that is already a well-known fact about IBM engineering roles.

397.authorInfo: Verified User Current Employee  d******  Software Developer - Nov 23, 2021

398.desc: Totally depends on management chain and client
398.pros: Rating IBM is like the story of the blind men and the elephant: what it's like depends almost completely on your first and second level up line managers, combined with whatever your primary client is (assuming you're primarily billable and not part of an internal R&D or development team). Where I am, I'd say it's pretty good. I've got a steady client, I don't have to spend a lot of time and energy finding work/projects, and management knows how valuable the skills of my small team are.
398.cons: Despite a lot of positive spin, and an ongoing attempt to reinvent itself (again) as a cloud analytics and hybrid cloud provider, IBM still feels like a sinking ship sometimes. Too much middle management, trying to do too many things at once, and the more than occasional short-sighted decisions make it challenging to defend being there. Combine that with meager annual increases and benefits that get expensive quickly when you have more than one child to cover, and the cons start to loom. Other times, like when I hear news about the 100-qubit quantum computer just released, and see proactive, progressive policies for equality of all kinds, a clear and firm code of ethics, and active encouragement for reporting of unfair/unequal/unethical behavior, I'm proud to be an IBMer.

406.pros: It's the company to be in if you need a place to park yourself, where what you say matters (not what you do). If you can spend all your time manipulating your boss and others, you can pretend to work while running one or more side hustles that pay, are more interesting, innovative and rewarding.
406.cons: The company's leadership is confused about who they want to be when they grow up. All the old guard (from the Ginni Rometty days) is hiring more people like themselves - not people who have depth of knowledge, but people who good on LinkedIn. They care about perception in the market and the stock price, they don't care two hoots about making good product and doing right by the customers.  IBM HR is the worst. They are bullies. Technology is a black box to them and are shockingly unaware of what makes a good candidate, but feel entitled to make decisions about good / bad candidates. Again, remnants of the Ginni days.  Everything IBM talks about - empathy, coaching leadership style, diversity, inclusion, mental health - are empty words. All talk, no walk. In a recent company-wide coaches (managers) survey, only 6% of IBM executives received a rating of good manager. Infighting, politics, backbiting, lying, scheming are all every day occurrences. It's pitiful.

488.pros: I've worked for IBM for over 5 years and I've learned a lot over that time—through sponsored external education and testing methods from books in my day to day work. This can be a great place to learn and grow your career with the right mentors and managers, but you own your career here—no one else. Expect to read books, take classes to help set the strategy for a 100+ year company to pivot into the age of cloud computing and AI. That's what you were hired for. If you enjoy navigating ambiguity and setting strategies, this can be an interesting place to work. Unlike some other companies, you can log off at 5pm and no one is going to fault you for enjoying your life.
488.cons: It's a large corporate company with a ton of bureaucracy. It can take an unnecessarily long time to do common sense things, largely because too many people don't understand digital marketing or marketing data. That lack of expertise can be incredibly frustrating when you have that expertise…but it's also an opportunity to practice communication skills and educate a workforce towards a common goal. With all that said, this has improved over the years but we still need to make more progress here.Culture can be a huge problem here depending on your team. I've been on toxic teams which will try to destroy your self esteem, but I've also been on empowering teams which encourage you to take more risks. Aligning yourself to the right teams will be critical to your success at this company. Additionally while the company is restructuring (at a massive scale) to help eliminate silos, it'll be interesting how the culture evolves with a smaller marketing workforce. Historically, team goals have been largely unaligned to other adjacent teams, making it challenging to achieve business outcomes. However, if goals are more aligned given the unification of teams across marketing, then the company could potentially make a lot of progress on business outcomes in the future. Remains to be seen.

You basically find what you're good at and dig in. The managers mean well and there aren't any crazy egos to deal with. The best ideas win.

611.desc: Horrible good old boys system exist
611.pros: Lost of projects since last 4 years became 50% remote, which was good, but this is because that the end client trend, IBM leadership did not do anything.
611.cons: Lots.Good old boys/girls exists, so, they promote the folks (though they are not qualified nor talented to be promoted) they know and who has buttering  capabilities. I have seen since 11 years, lot of junior folks, untalented got promoted from consultant to Senior managers within 4 to 6 years (because they are part of gang) and people who talented, who delivered high quality work, promise them each year that you will get promoted, but, never promote them. Trick is, keep moving them (people who are not part of the gang) to other managers, so one manager promises, by the time you are eligible, you are moved to another, he says, I can't promote you, I don't you, the cycle continues. the Middle management socks, they never keep their promises. The APs and Partners keep the bonuses to themselves (selfish leaders), does not share with the teams (except if you are part of the gang), in 11 years, got 3 times bonus, once 3k, 2 other times, $400 and $600 (yes, I am not kidding). Many years worked on 2 projects, gigs, but still not a single thank you note (because you are not part of the gang). The middle management is horrible liers (when it comes career growth and promotions). They have lot of mandatory yearly trainings, but it is just for showoff. The training talks about honesty, true leadership, keeping up the promise, morality, but, most of middle management does not follow especially when it comes to recognizing the good work, though end client recognizes and promotion is only for people  who are part of the gang. Recently (may be last 3 years), if you are between projects, they assign you to bench managers, they literally harass you. You have find your own project with your connections, there are no recruiters anymore. Their Public sector/Federal practice is nothing but mafia gang, good old boys/girls syste. The APs and Partners does not hire IBM FTEs on project, though you are highly qualified first preference given to contractors who they know, IBM federal projects are practically run by contractors may be APs and Partners may have under the table dealing exists hence most contractors are working on IBM projects for 12 to 15 years, they can hire them as FTE, but APs and Parters, never high them and keep them contractors. I wish I would have left early.

731.desc: Classic tech company with interesting problems, but awful workplace culture
731.pros: • If you set your boundaries, decent work-life balance. People seem to be able to wfh anytime. If you're looking to chill, a great place to do it.• Classic workplace amenities: free snacks, drinks, coffee. • Brilliant engineers at the top. If you're hardworking and smart, there are interesting problems to solve. • Most people are decent, nice, and helpful. I genuinely appreciated their help and felt welcome.• Everyone of all hierarchies is accessible. • Classic brand name and big company. Allows lots of opportunities inside and outside the companies.
731.cons: • Relatively low compensation. The company can't hire the best of the best because they pay below-market-rate in my opinion. • A few bad apples. While every company has them, it speaks to the workplace culture and behavioral hiring bar. I was harassed by someone with zero social skills and only my mentor understood and stood up for me. Asked my harasser who knew his behavior was inappropriate if he ever got an HR report and he said none, which is very telling.• Very little diversity. People are welcoming, but eventually, you get left out of cliques.• Management is disorganized and does not keep promises. They do not keep track of the bigger picture.
731.resignation reason: Manager doesn't keep his promises. I couldn't change teams. I was being harassed, but who would believe a newbie over someone who hides behind his long tenure? I was just done. I spent a few months with no offer but got one at another company with a notorious reputation. However, my experience there has been miles better than at IBM so far.
731.authorInfo: Verified User Former Employee  l********  Full Stack Developer - Jun 12, 2021

789.pros: - Great work life balance. No hard push. Infrequent deadline.- Very flexible management. I'm not in a remote position, but management is generally flexible if you have anything and want to work remotely on that day.- Free Udemy business. Very helpful in building skills.- Excellent 401k plan. This is one of the the best 401k plans among tech companies I've seen for investment geeks who value the advantages of tax-advantaged investment accounts.  - Match up to 6% of the base (by contributing 5% of your base). This is further enhanced due to the fact that IBM doesn't generally award bonus --- the base is usually 20% higher than other big corps in the area. This results in more company match than Google (also arguably the best 401k plan) if you contribute no less than 5% of your base for mid-level positions.  - Employees can contribute to 10% after-tax.  - The investment choices are well structured. All core investments for a basic portfolio are available at low cost, plus many low-cost extended choices, such as Dimensional Fund Advisor (DFA) funds.
789.cons: - Total compensation is generally not as good as other big corps.- Company work pace is slow. The good aspect is that everyone is slow, the bad aspect is that... everything you request others is slow as well.- The pace is slow, again. This means that career growth may be more difficult than elsewhere. If you need to learn from work, this is not a good place. But if you are confident in your skills and can manage to do some influential side projects, this can be turned to an advantage (Company projects, which are often shitty, won't bother you too much).

The company isn't competitive, and while it's trying to right the ship, the same message has been touted for years, and people know it's not working sufficiently. Base pay is decent, but with so many companies giving equity, IBM's compensation falls very short. I have been giving way fewer responsibilities than I'm capable of and I haven't felt challenged.

Jim Whitehurst is trying to change the culture - good ama channel asking hard questions. If he becomes CEO IBM has a shot.6. Leaders in quantum computing, security, and blockchain (best areas to join in company)7. 401K is above average with 100% of 6% of salary. Have little ways to incentivize since HR and Finance plus executives control it and promotions.3. GBS and GTS should be avoided at all costs4. Zero accountability at executive level; out of touch with market 5. Focus on EPS continues or hedge funds will dump IBM stock and executives will lose their jobs which they are trying to avoid. 1201.desc: management driving this company into the ground!

1201.cons: Executive compensation is based on individual performance. Individual contributor compensation is based on company performance. Executives are greedy and self motivated, hell bent on driving the company into the ground at the expense of promoting and paying to retain capable staff from within the ranks. There is no coherent strategy set by leadership other than get my pay raise and get my bonus. Employees are the ones who suffer in this completely backward organizatonal set up.
